subject: Custom Ant Testrunner for Java Annotations
msgSnippet: At work we have been playing around with java annotations, ant, and junit.  Ant has different formatters you can use to create junit reports from a junit run
messageBody:
At work we have been playing around with java annotations, ant, and
junit. Ant has different formatters you can use to create junit
reports from a junit run which all derive from a common base class,
easily overrideable, and customizable in the junitreport ant task.

JUnitResultFormatter (Apache Ant API)
http://freak.homeip.net/doc/ant-1.6.5/manual/api/org/apache/tools/ant/taskdefs/optional/junit/JUnitResultFormatter.html

JUnit Ant Task
http://ant.apache.org/manual/OptionalTasks/junit.html

Currently we are using a custom formatter to pick up the annotations
on a test, create xml, and then implementing custom XSLT run the junitreport
task. This has allowed us to tag tests in the code with bug numbers,
notes, version numbers, email addresses to notify on failure, and sort
into groups on the web report depending on the state (production, dev,
quarantined).

I am currently working on a solution to write a custom junit runner
which accompanies the formatter so engineers can run all tests in a
specific package that are in dev or production or have a specific
version. I couldn't find any documentation in ant of an easy way to
plugin a custom runner to the junit task. I considered deriving from
the ant JUnitTestRunner as I would gain the benefit of it
automatically calling my custom formatter for me, but I can't figure
out how to get the JUnit ant task to run my testrunner instead of the
default ant
test runner.

http://freak.homeip.net/doc/ant-1.6.5/manual/api/org/apache/tools/ant/taskdefs/optional/junit/JUnitTestRunner.html

Since I cannot find an easy way to use a custom JUnit test runner with
the Ant JUnit task, I am probably going to write my own task which
calls my custom runner. Writing the task won't be too difficult, but
I would love to have my own runner logic describing which tests to run
based on custom annotations, with the benefits of managed threading,
formatter, timeouts, and anything else that may come with future
releases of the Ant JUnit task. Not to mention as little work as
possible in updating our current build scripts that run the tests.

If anyone knows something being released in the new version of Ant, I
would love to know. I read through their beta manual and couldn't
find any mention of implementing a custom test runner or any custom
interface that extends junit.framework.TestListener.

http://ant.apache.org/manual-beta/

Thank in advance!

~Danny
